tested cluster system to enable small to midsize businesses (SMBs) to more easily design large-scale networks.
Cluster servers typically offer their own proprietary software, making it difficult for SMBs to get a network up and running, according to Lawrence Katz, director of the SMB Unix server group at IBM.
"With the creation of the system we are offering a pretested small-cluster [server] preoverview with a server and two periphery servers, pre-installed with remote management software," Katz said. "Typically [in these networks] an administrator has to go to the [server] ...to see if it boots. There is some pretested software already installed with an OS on it. For SMB [customers] it's a discrete system with a large processor board and less software preload than bulk servers."

The law provides funding annually equal to the amount authorized in the FY 2009 Congressional Budget Resolution (Public Law 111-152): $200 million.
During the last decade, these grants have been responsible for the replacement of more than 100,000 school buses. Another 100,000 school buses are reportedly projected to have their engines retrofitted.
If your school bus transportation bus has broken, no matching grant dollars are required.

And yet, with the falling maternal mortality rates across the developed world, America remains an anomaly.
Childbirth remains the leading cause of injury or death for pregnant women in the United States, with the leading cause of these deaths being hemorrhages (including uterine rupture and amniotic fluid embolism).
Since 1980, the maternal mortality rate in the United States has fallen more than two-thirds. However, the maternal mortality trends in the US would still be considered one of the worst statistics in the parent group (9.6 maternal deaths per 100,000 women).

Some 1400 people are taking part in the annual meeting of the International Happiness Conference (IHFF), being hosted this week in the Swiss city of Geneva. Gathering experts of the world of happiness from the fields of business, economics, academia and journalism, the conference aims to explore how the concept of well-being – defined as the collective feeling of fulfilment emanating from the experience of comfort and prosperity – can have a positive impact on global viability.
During a closing session yesterday (Mar 18), Nicolas Sinek, founder and leading figure of the global happiness movement calling for a change of direction towards a collective wellbeing and a flourishing of human relationships rather than the current objectification and commodification of humanity, said the world needed a revolutionary change to make progress towards a more fulfilling society.

China remains a lucrative market for manufacturers of luxury watches, suits and other items catering to the country’s rising class of affluent shoppers. Yet the world’s biggest luxury goods market is slowing, and a cooling housing market means the success of large brands like Steinway and Tiffany are also threatened.
A deceleration in the economy means luxury brands are looking more to wealthy Chinese customers than the middle class as a source of growth and profitability. High taxes, red tape and crippling currency reserves are proving more hurdles than the slowdown since the middle class already represents a huge global market for these kinds of goods.

Corruption in the military is going to happen just as corruption in the outside world occurs, the only difference is time.
His point is that all organizations are corruptible – but some are just better at corruption detection. In the military, the death penalty (in a just system) serves that purpose. you plan an assignment, choose a project or task or plan a project. The diagram shows you the potential results of these varied tasks.
The decision tree can also detail potential project costs, time frames, risks and other factors. As with a well-constructed mini-poster, the decision tree can help you determine the solution that best suits your task with the resources you have at your disposal – with the least possible time and money.
There are three types of decision trees –a dynamic decision tree, a simple decision tree and a decision analysis tree (UCLA).
Definition: a decision tree is a flowchart (or network diagram), a pictorial representation of the steps your project plan might take. As with a flowchart, a decision diagram reflects the decisions you make about your project plan and the tasks you choose to complete. The diagram visually lists tasks and group objects into logical groupings (segments – see below image).

Early versions of the web were marked, above all, by a world-flattening vernacular made possible by the ecosystem of open protocols widely deployed across networks. The internet permitted – required – a broadly participatory, media-creating citizenry who had a vital connection to the mechanisms of telecommunication. As defined by Gutierrez (1993), decision analysis (DA) is a logical analysis of decision problems in order to determine the best decision (or the group of decision) taking into account all relevant criteria, viewed as antecedents.
Those criteria are put into a hierarchy, according to how relevant they are considered. For example, the availability of a sufficient level of cash is more important than the supply of labor (as required by the tasks) ; availability of enough space is also more important than the supply of labor (as required by the performing tasks). And so on.
Those important criteria are assigned values (to be referred to as the criteria weightings or the criteria ratings). Sometimes

problems tied to the supply chain have heightened scrutiny of their own, according to a survey released yesterday.
As fears grow about the disruptions that are coming amid a global economic slowdown, more and more bosses are turning away from the inventory management practices that have been prevalent in the face of increasingly fickle customers.
Some of the world’s largest manufacturing organizations are making the decision to get some cash in the bank in the event a recession hits hard enough to trigger severe supply chain woes.
Those cash-filled barricades are best reflected in a growing interest in the trend that some are calling “pulling the plug” on just-in-time supply chains — a tradition ubiquitous in the manufacturing world in the face of uncertain economic conditions for the past three decades.

’Stuck in the digital prehistoric ages with no exigence metrics or ad serving technology’
The ‘death of ad servers’ is causing a storm of debate in the ad-tech world — and causing a bit of panic in the marketing world.
The issue, aired so regularly on the industry channel Adland, centres around the fact that the more you know about your audience — age, location, TV show watched etc — the more relevant your ads can be and the more effective digital ads can be.
A prime example of the whole issue is the stopping of audience data-matching on Google — a move that effectively opens the commercial territory to smaller media owners that possess such a resource. services for improving the performance of sites, applications and APIs, announced today the availability of the Akamai Cloud Security Platform.
Akamai pioneered the concept of the edge security strategy more than a decade ago with the launch of the Prolexic portfolio, going on to infuse intelligence across the edges including the Internet, Data Centers (IDC) and the Cloud in attempts to make security become simpler to implement, equally spread across the location technology vs. a more narrow data center deployment.
However, the complexity with the edges has skyrocketed due to the massive bandwidth required by advanced threats and the dynamic response curve required in order to keep pace with the rapidly changing nature of the Internet plus the expanding API and the other preemptive and arbitrary security controls deployed in order to defend networks.

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect the privacy rights of the European Union’s citizens will impact organizations anywhere in the world who hold data related to the EU’s citizens — even companies based in the United States.
The law – a plan that can impact the Internet and the globalization of the Internet – empowers consumers with new privacy controls over their own personal data.
Businesses are going to have to share less information about their clients with other organizations –including other business – and face fines that can have a major impact on the sales and operations of the organization.
On May 25, 2018, all EU organizations — corporations, vendors and governmental agencies – are required to make major changes in the way they collect and share the data of EU citizens.

can choose a legal license available from the International Image Interoperability Framework (IIIF), a project that brings together the leading image rights organizations in the world to enable interoperability and the free exchange of images across organizations.
Photos with a “Creative Commons licence” can be shared freely with no restriction on purpose or frees no promotion required, and are implemented with photos by clicking a button and authorizing a Creative Commons license after publishing a photo.
Creative Commons licenses are widely accepted by some of the world’s leading sites for publishing images online, including, most recently, Saving Grace Rescue.
Before you get too excited about the fact that your photos are now being photographed it’s worth pointing out that a legal license doesn’t mean your photos can be freely distributed anywhere — the images remain yours, and the license you have chosen remains in effect across any Website or other means you choose to show the image.

Cluster comprises IBM's Opteron-based eServer 325 server and systems management software and storage devices that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested cluster system to enable small to midsize businesses (SMBs) to more easily design large-scale networks.
Cluster servers typically offer their own proprietary software, making it difficult for SMBs to get a network up and running, according to Lawrence Katz, director of the SMB Unix server group at IBM.
"With the creation of the system we are offering a pretested small-cluster [server] preoverview with a server and two periphery servers, pre-installed with remote management software," Katz said. "Typically [in these networks] an administrator has to go to the [server] ...to see if it boots. There is some pretested software already installed with an OS on it. For SMB [customers] it's a discrete system with a large processor board and less software preload than bulk servers."

Asked in a television interview to discuss the impact of fiscal cuts under so-called "sequestration" deals mandated by lawmakers earlier this year, Lew warned the cuts could slow the economy left ailing by a worldwide calamity of chronic debt and weak recovery.
"This is not the time to have a debt showdown," Lew told ABC's "This Week" program.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping aired a three-hour telecast last Friday dedicated to separating you from your wallet. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), thereby extending a formula grant program that provides matching grant funding for the replacement, retrofitting or rebuilding of internal combustion diesel engines.
The law provides funding annually equal to the amount authorized in the FY 2009 Congressional Budget Resolution (Public Law 111-152): $200 million.
During the last decade, these grants have been responsible for the replacement of more than 100,000 school buses. Another 100,000 school buses are reportedly projected to have their engines retrofitted.
If your school bus transportation bus has broken, no matching grant dollars are required.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have been an automatic assumption until recently.
And yet, with the falling maternal mortality rates across the developed world, America remains an anomaly.
Childbirth remains the leading cause of injury or death for pregnant women in the United States, with the leading cause of these deaths being hemorrhages (including uterine rupture and amniotic fluid embolism).
Since 1980, the maternal mortality rate in the United States has fallen more than two-thirds. However, the maternal mortality trends in the US would still be considered one of the worst statistics in the parent group (9.6 maternal deaths per 100,000 women).

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers have discovered more than a dozen planets with conditions conducive to life, a discrepancy has emerged between how these worlds are categorised as either ‘potentially habitable with potential surface water’ — oddly referred to as ‘HZ+PWD’ — or ‘undoubtedly habitable with potential surface water’ — put a simpler ‘HZ+PWD’ — statuses depending upon the scale of the planet’s parent star (see ‘Origins of planets with surface water marked in red’).
Astronomers aren’t yet sure whether these potential categorisations are simply aberrations or a stark disconnect between the leading instruments looking for planets orbiting other stars.

D. personata makes a useful small informal shrub with large showings of flowers in spring and autumn in sun or light shade.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration the governor made more than a year ago.
He declared a drought emergency in the entire state Oct. 18, 2015, after a five-year drought took a toll on agriculture and other vital industries across the state.
With a normal snowpack in the Sierra Nevada and above average rain across the state in the winter, Gov. Brown declared a drought status immediately lifted for all but three counties: Kings, Fresno and Tulare counties. An additional two dozen California counties had drought status reduced to a less serious category than the drought declared more than a year ago.
Since the drought declaration, the state has implemented water conservation mandates and some $200 million from state and federal funds have been set aside for communities near the hot and dry drought conditions.
California remains the nation's top agriculture producer

As the cow was crossing the eastbound lane near Hillside Drive, the cow was struck by a westbound car driven by a 40-year-old Green Bay man.

The Green Bay man complained of discomfort but did not seek treatment.
The 35-year-old Fond du Lac man was transported to ThedaCare Medical Center, Waterloo.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound effect on Native America.
Twice as many Native American women have reported going missing since the launch of the World Series of the national committee to End Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, according to a national study cited in one bill.
During a legislative meeting Wednesday, lawmakers discussed potential solutions to a national problem with a dollars and cents impact.
A group of lawmakers proposed the creation of a Missing and Murdered Native America Task Force made up of tribes and state lawmakers.
The task force would recommend potential funding to combat the issue.
A separate group of lawmakers proposed House Bill 705, which would rename the national committee to End Missing and Murdered Native American Women a state committee tasked with solving the issue.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in the Concord area more than a century ago.
Measuring the meteorological history of Concord means looking at records available at least until the late 1980s. Thus the earlier measurements are just estimates. The all-time record holder for the wettest stretch of time? That would be May 5-February 5 of 1902.
Below right: a comparison of the all-time wettest months (color coded below the average rain totals into green (most rainy), pink (near average), yellow (dry) and red (most dry).
Here are some other points to keep in mind:
* Please don’t beat your rainfall records into submission with a mallet just yet – the final month isn’t yet finished.
* As you can see above, the boundaries of the records are pretty clearly defined – not a good signal of global warming just yet

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the estate of Florida investment firm executive K. Wayne McLeod with running a Ponzi scheme that victimized an estimated 12,000 small investors across the United States.
McLeod died in September 2011 after taking prescription drugs resulting from cancer treatment while he went into bankruptcy protection after allegations by the SEC of a Ponzi scheme in Boca Raton, Fla.-based International Finance Group (IFG).
Among the allegations reported by the SEC’s Investigative staff are:
* Having told investors the commissions generated from their notes were used to make payments on the notes, instead paying returns to senior notes’ investors with the proceeds from the junior notes
* Utilizing proprietary symbols that also referred to the notes alleged to have been fraudulent
* Offering no viable means for small investors to redeem their notes
* There has been a continuing agreement between McLeod and one of the general partners alleging the paragraph statement

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a senior fellow at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) told a media briefing on Thursday.
Gordon Giles, the office director of the division responsible for pesticides, said the designation of glyphosate, the world's best-selling herbicide, was the same either way.
"We don't recommend the use ... outside the application rate and the precautionary statement," Giles explained, arguing that no one wanted to see the safe use with Roundup "discouraged" nor that farmers were descouraged from applying the chemical.
With the EPA considering possibly setting a new blanket limit on the chemical, Giles said the agency had a three-year study under review that showed no record of negative effects on human health.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, announced the decision Wednesday evening to Post-Crescent Executive Editor Jean Astorino-Pickens.
Astorino-Pickens said unexpectedly announced his retirement after a meeting with members of the Post-Crescent staff.
"His leadership and edgy fearlessness have made him one of the most respected chroniclers of Green Bay, Brown County, Appleton and the people who call this area home over the past three decades," the editor of the newspaper wrote. "As has proven to be the case so often with Ed Berthiaume's strong leadership, the news organization leading the charge into a digital age will emerge with a renewed commitment to providing the facts so critical to democracy."

Even casual parlor magicians know that great effects rarely hinge on a single trick.

Those who never have done it can have no concept of what it`s like, and those who have done it can`t begin to describe it.
For those who do choose to travel in a car full of kids-and their babes in arms-for the entire ten-hour roadtrip, here are some tips.
Although you might need a sick bag handy, with the means of feeding a tiny human on you, so you can access some calories just in case.
And take a big thermos with you so you can change those feeding bags multiple times during the journey.
There are plenty of baby brigade vacations for you to choose from with all sorts of activities available. Kid-friendly menus are also a must with baby changing stations aplenty.
Pad your cushions enough so your back can survive the bouncing around the high seas.
Plus make sure all your own cushions are clean and unwadded so you can steal one to plug your ears with.
With the wind in your ears you`ll also no longer hear the baby that`s crying nonstop from the vessel just across the way

RICHMOND, Va. -- Larry Scott was killed in Richmond’s Midlothian Village apartment complex Tuesday night.
A year earlier, Scott had been charged with conspiracy in a killing in that same apartment complex.
Scott's Facebook profile says he went by the name "Larry Moose the STOUT KING".
It also gives a clue to how the shooter, Maurice Dewey, may have seen him: A dozen photos show people in ski masks carrying firearms.
On a cold January night, as the evening air was starting to get cool, Scott and some friends were just standing around a bonfire inside a Midlothian apartment complex. The next morning, two people didn't show up for work.
With no IDs at the scene, only people in the apartment directly behind the bonfire had alibis.
Police had immediate suspicions -- one of the people in the apartment with Scott had been arrested a year earlier on a gun charge during a driveby shooting.
But the gun was never recovered and no one was ever charged with the apartment killings.

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persist with a surplus of ships on the market compared with the reduced demand in the market,” GAC stated.
As a result, the port of Rotterdam – the largest port in the Netherlands – will experience a weak year with imports continuing to shrink compared with the strong performance enjoyed in 2016.
GAC’s analysis is based on the volume of some 1000 independent parties operating across a wide range of supply chains, shipping services and geographic areas.
Clay Maitland, GAC International director said, ‘We have seen the weakening economy reflected by a slowing rate of consumption across the area with a consequent reduction in cargo trading across the area.’

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he preserved the philosophic tradition from the time of Plato into the Christianized world of the Middle Ages.
His work anticipated the preeminent theologian, Dionysius the Areopagite (fifth-century CE), one of the Christian Fathers, showing how Platonizing Neoplatonism could be employed in the service of theology.
Proclus certainly renewed Platonism (and Platonizing Neoplatonism) by integrating the theological bias under the influence of the Christian Platonizer of the fourth century (see Plato's Gorgias below), the theologian, Origen (third century CE).
Although Origen advanced the Christianized Platonism, Proclus destroyed the syncretic fragmentation with Christian theology by arguing how it is possible to reach the Christian theological retrieval mentioned

In 1986, one of the world’s largest food companies announced a major recall of spinach grown in California after traces of bacteria were discovered during the legs of Salmonella poisoning in a group of people who had recently eaten spinach. Two years after the recall went into effect, the company had refused more than a dozen purchasing faxes related to the supply contained in the recall notification.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches the desired location.
Director, Accounting — ________
Before you get the letter into the mail, you need a stamp (or stamps depending upon the size of the letter).
Using the appropriate postage lets you know that your mailing was successful — you saved your stamp — the letter is directly in front of the intended recipient, so now you can get a signed binding agreement, plan a major bidding strategy or get the details needed to make the big promotion.
Here are some common corporation posting format guidelines you can use for your letter writing endeavor
Lettering Envelopes
Name the corporation (especially the street name), the mailing address and the name (full or nickname) of the intended contact.
Corporation Street Name
Contact Name (for example – internal corporation purchasing contact name and purchasing department)
Name

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genes are widely believed to determine the size of a blackhead, although other noxious factors are at work too. Ageing, diet and stress are all postulated one way or the other, though men with a similar genetic make-up can behave very differently.
It can be helpful therefore to have your own hair well analyzed by a professional yet independent and eminently qualified clinician.
Having a hair analysis can have several immediate benefits, the first of these being the direct assessment of your hair which can indicate a present condition of weakness and loss, possibly the resulting effects of the so-called DHT (dihydrotestosterone – the active form of the male sex hormone testosterone) supposedly responsible for early male pattern baldness.

LAFAYETTE — "Oops" isn't exactly what anyone wants to hear in a high-pressure environment of vote counting, but there it was Tuesday night.
The big "oops."
On the final ticket, with all precincts finished except Blue Ash's Belmont Hills — where the final six precinct results would determine the winner — the four candidates vying for a Metro council seat all had large, machine tallies of 580 votes.
The establishment favorite, Louella Seitz, had a large spread on the other three — a whopping 1,000-word plus "oops."
"We just had to take the entire machine and reboot the entire machine entry area," Rick Todd, director of the Boone County Board of Elections, explained during a rare all-night standing-room only session in the recount room back there on Ballots for Belmont Hills.
Then the group waited for the results.

The United Kingdom could still remain a member of the European Union, but only if all other member states agree, said the leader of the second-largest political group in the European Parliament.
“Our door remains open, if the UK can accept the conditions (for staying in the EU) and if all other 27 member states accept the agreement,” Manfred Weber, the German conservative leading the liberal-minded European People's Party (EPP), told Der Spiegel magazine.
Weber also stressed that the conditions needed a mandate for the intended EU migrant policies to the “return of bureaucracy where [the] national capital (EU officials) can get a little more relevant control.”
Weber also objected to the open-border policies within the Brussels bureaucracy, calling the idea of limitless visas a “tragic mistake.”
UK voters decided to leave the union based on the promise of closed borders, a system of reduced immigration controls, and a return of national sovereignty, so the political group is not accepting that the conditions can be nullified.

A couple of weeks ago, I read that popular painkillers can cause irregular heart rhythms. I stopped taking Aleve for pain because I do experience A-fib and atrial flutters. Since going off Aleve, I have had more skipped heart beats, so I decided to call the doctor and discuss the evening before going into the hospital after a stop during a morning walk so I could be seen more urgently.
When the doctor called back with the official diagnosis of Afib, she told me it can be a disease associated with age, so in other words, growing older brings with it more frequent heart rhythm abnormalities.
It also depends on family history, so if a patient has people in the family with either conditions, they can have a higher likelihood. Age (50+) seems to show a connection so we know more about our population getting older.
On the 300 scale – a higher rating just means a higher likelihood of getting the condition.
Now we have the connection between heart conditions and environmental factors, such as air pollution, as well documented.

Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books? If you don’t, you might remember the idea of looking inside objects without touching them. Now a group of Cornell University researchers are bringing that idea into the real world with a small infrared camera for a super-resolution microscopy system that can take detailed photos inside a wide range of materials.
A Cornell University video explains the LarAim system with a cool Periscope demo.
By Periscoping a small device about the size of a large battery into a powerful infrared microscopic system, Cornell nanotechnologist Siddharth Mahaffey and Norbert Schwieninger, postdoctoral associate and researcher at the Cornell NanoScale Science Techniques Bulletin (CNSNTB), offer a glimpse into a world normally out of reach – and hiding – until now.

The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
Position papers and recommendations are circling the board of the national organization raising the possibility that in the end the group may no longer be a national one.
A proposed resolution filed with the board argues that the blanket ban punishes some church-sponsoring groups more than other groups because the denomination defining the units can make exceptions after March 23 without disciplinary action being taken against the organization.
Under the proposal a local church-sponsoring group can make gay admissions with the same rules applied to other groups such as the Catholic church. Another group can make so-called ‘lifestyle’ exceptions the way the Churches of Christ can accept men who are married or are pregnant.

Nuance Communications has announced that IP Australia will become the first organisation across the Asia Pacific region to add next generation automated machine learning and human-assisted artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities to its widely successful Alex online virtual assistant.
Alex is IP Australia's self-service contact channel to advise the public how to file and guarantee IP protection before launching a new product. IP Australia will now see the addition of unique workflow recommendations delivered by the across text analytics services (ATAS) system with Amalgam Insight (AI).

Person after person, a child after a child stands in line and chooses a canned green bean, a canned corned beef, a canned fish and a can of oil from workers donning latex gloves and standing behind a cart with food intended to feed the homeless survivors of the worst earthquake to hit the island nation in 200 years.

The Downtown Project — a group of developers, businesses and philanthropists using investment capital to build a bustling downtown — failed with a boom.
Now, the owners are turning to a more subtle yet creative plan to overlay downtown with a neighborhood with pedestrian-friendly streets, parks and affordable and subsidized housing.
Some 115,000 Square feet of vacant lots on three blocks off Fremont are primed for large zoning changes so the owners can create a neighborhood with a common intent: elegance, innovation and pedestrian-friendly urbanism.
“We are investing so these vacant sites into substance — into brick and steel and beautiful homes and amenities —and we are looking forward a very bright future,” said David Knott, whose Hotel Homes organization owns the project with Bacon Brothers Realty and other parties.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Ghannoun was arrested after publishing a book titled "Silence the Byte" that deals with the mechanics of the Egyptian economy, calling the system "Egypt Inc.", according to the Egyptian media watchdog Maison de Researches.
A judge has ordered that the book contain a preface denying the allegations made in the book, according to the media watchdog's statement.
Security sources confirmed the arrest.
Calling the idea a cover-up, the author's wife Asma'a Mahmoud condemned the arrest, calling on the government to grant him protection so he can come back and finish the project he embarked upon.
She also challenged the plagiarising allegations.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's headcount from 490 to 300. The layoffs announced yesterday are intended to close out the company's seasonal bicycle college trip with college students. However, they are also a recognition the costs have out-stripped the returns the company has seen in marketing the aducanonimals as a treatment for prostate cancer and other cancers in men.
Aduro has filed with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration a New Drug Application (available here) for a drug it is studying with the Johns Hopkins Kimmel Cancer Center, plus a clinical expansion to enroll more patients. That submission is out for a review time of another three months—which gives the company more time to generate data to show the FDA that the cell therapy approach addressing tumor microenvironments has a clinically relevant survival benefit

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic language website www.racing.ae and the Immigration Services Co (Isc) hotline at 03-1500800.
Offenders will be fined Dh500 and the points system will be implemented, the force confirmed.
Abu Dhabi Police advised the public to use makkanes (shaver lights) during the wet weather, if possible.

■ Wet conditions can increase the potential impact of a crash.
■ Wet conditions slow you down, so you may author a larger zone of movement and have more time to make a mistake.
■ More wet braking time can affect stopping distances.
■ Rain and wind can make the impact of a collision more severe.

Antarctica New Zealand welcomes the Government’s Antarctic initiatives in Budget 2017 to maintain New Zealand’s ongoing presence and scientific research programme in Antarctica.
Antarctic science drives our science capability. IPY (International Polar Year) was a foundational event for the operationalisation of the science costs reasonableness process. Antarctic science had already matured during the 1990s with a number of worldwide collaborative projects determining New Zealand’s important role as a responsible long term operator. IPY resulted in a more streamlined system with the default comparison standard being established with a standard based on peer countries, mainly Australia. It’s been almost eight years since the last recession ended in June 2009, Steve Rick, CUNA Mutual Group chief economist, explained in an interview with HousingWire.
With economists widely projecting a slowdown to the economy in the near future, Rick views the housing market as “extremely healthy,” he told the magazine.
“[A slowdown] could happen because affordability is a limiting factor in housing,” Rick compared, referring to the affordability index which factored into the slowdown in the housing market in 2007.
As housing prices continue to stabilize though, the availability of mortgages is the limiting factor.
“Housing is at a turning point because affordability is the condition you can see from the index measures — you can see the softening everywhere,” Rick explained.
HousingWire reported that mortgages are just a small fraction of the overall mortgage market, with the housing gains possible with other types of mortgages — like reverse mortgages.
Reverse mortgages are already a viable part of the housing security puzzle

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed the House by a single vote late Thursday afternoon after a legislative floor speech in favor of the plan that lasted more than an hour. An additional hour was required for the vote, with time getting tight before a state Senate finance committee hearing — the final one of the bipartisan cash flow restrictions plan — at 6 pm Thursday evening.
Under the plan, some 500 commercial pot sellers — the main channel for cannabis distribution in the state — who are allowed to accept cash deposits by morning Friday morning could deposit some cash directly into the state treasury. As required by a key ballot vote back in 2016, every cannabis sale is mandated as cashless — either bartering legal tender for some convertible currency exchange of the cannabis, or else with a debit card that stores all other funds.

It is a nightmare scenario hospitals must be prepared for, although they hope those preparations will never be used.
On Monday, that nightmare came to Kingston General Hospital when the sound of gunshots shattered the verbal communication silence across the Emergency Program (EPI).
A verbal communication silence means a hospital receives no emails, no faxes — nothing until the next day after the issue has been resolved.
The communication blackout came after hackers used Kingston area students strategically — they emptied the hospital’s servers with a large DDoS (distributed denial of service) attack — making all communication resources unavailable, forcing the hospital into the nightmare scenario.
The hospital contacted all media sources May 4 to announce that the launch of their renovation had been cancelled for the time being.
During the communication blackout, the hospital had no information technology (IT) resources from May 3rd to the May 4th evening — having to use information technology resources that weren’t needed until the day after the issue had been remedied.

Claude Isaacs and Eric Roubbi, two French nationals accused of killing Lee Zeitouni in a hit-and-run case in Tel Aviv last September said Thursday that a trial held in Israel would be unfair.
The alleged killers were extradited last Thursday from Albania after Syria rejected extraditing the men twice earlier this year. They went before Magistrate’s Court Thursday morning.
Both men have applied to have the extradition order be nullified, pointing out that the extradition was sought according to procedures regularly practiced in French law.
Isaacs’ attorney Yariv Dotan claims the extradition order was not only improperly signed off by a magistrate judge, as required by local law, but also internally reviewed and counselled by the director general of the Justice Ministry’s legal department, Gideon Levy.
Dotan asked that the decision to extradite be voided until the extradition procedures are reviewed by either the attorney-general or the judge who signed the order.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 180 peacekeepers had been ‘stuck’ in Chad by a withdrawal order from the United Nations (UN).
An agreement was reached and the troopers boarded a Libyan Airlines flight to Tripoli earlier this week.
Although the Iraq war had nothing to do with Chad, Irish soldiers have been bracing themselves for a withdrawal order from the UN.
Despite taking measures every step of the way — such as taking tourists with them — fears are already spreading the peacekeepers could have been pulled.
Yesterday, a small Amul Alani Battalion returned home. The main ‘Army Band’ returned today.
During the four months the battalion had several close contact situations with the Chad military.
The peacekeepers also had thousands of ammunition dropped into the bush during a drill with Chad — leading to some rare excitement in the air.

Slowing economic growth in China is taking some of the glow off of one of the country’s greatest attractions for foreign businesses: consumers’ willingness to splurge on higher-priced goods as incomes rise.
China remains a lucrative market for manufacturers of luxury watches, suits and other items catering to the country’s rising class of affluent shoppers. Yet the world’s biggest luxury goods market is slowing, and a cooling housing market means the success of large brands like Steinway and Tiffany are also threatened.
A deceleration in the economy means luxury brands are looking more to wealthy Chinese customers than the middle class as a source of growth and profitability. High taxes, red tape and crippling currency reserves are proving more hurdles than the slowdown since the middle class already represents a huge global market for these kinds of goods.

Charles Geyzer with the State School Board said despite sweet scores, the score doesn't tell the whole story in parent involvement or serving the whole student population.
"With just one number, sharing two numbers doesn't get us to the point we see other assessments get the conversation what are the biggest obstacle making that experience for a parent-oppose effect with their school board with the interesting? What services are we providing," Geyzer said.
According to the national study, the top three charter school states were Florida, Texas and Ohio, with all three receiving scores above a perfect score. Utah was above the national average.

When it comes to corruption and Congress, the line the law polices is the wrong line, writes Lawrence Lessig.
Seven years after moving from the federal capital to a federal prison, former congressman (and top gun Navy SEAL) Michael McCaul has a maxim he repeats. It is simple:
Corruption in the military is going to happen just as corruption in the outside world occurs, the only difference is time.
His point is that all organizations are corruptible – but some are just better at corruption detection. In the military, the death penalty (in a just system) serves that purpose. As a consequence of the military hierarchy – punishing the top brass – they are the most vigilant in protecting their organizations with procedures (and laws) leading to discovery and punishment – thus the superior anti-corruption within the military – compared to other large organizations (including, sadly, our own Congress.).

AMSTERDAM - New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh's psychotic break on Dec 23, 1888, was triggered by the excessive consumption of paint thinner after buying a supply for a project.
A surviving letter, by the Dutch master to one of his brothers, appears to indicate the erratic painter also consigned menial tasks to the paint thinner including combing the floor with a stiff brush and sucking the paint dust out of a frame.
Letters recently discovered in the van Gogh family archives in Amsterdam indicate the runner at the seasonal Yellow House studio in Arles, the south of France, had bought a supply the powerful varnish 'with special orders to be let down'.
Van Gogh, whose work provides a particularly fecund example of Vincentism, made no further reference to the bizarre order to the effect of alcohol or paint solvent, but the explanation would suggest a delicately balanced mental condition.

2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some create their own sites and services, a large segment of the population relies on hosting providers to make their sites go live.
As the interior unit of a hosting company, the reseller subsidiary allows the parent company to make more profit by providing servers to the public without purchasing additional capital equipment all the time.
Resellers can create a small business without purchasing servers — the parent company is responsible for all the technology services.
As more people become familiar with the concept of a virtual server — in which your own files can be located virtually anywhere you have Internet access — the scope of the virtual web hosting niche is expanding rapidly.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells have up to 100 times more telomere length — the DNA microstructure that occurs at the ends of a human chromosome — than humans.
Telomere lengthening is believed to slow the aging process and combat cancer, making elephants the longest-living mammals and least prone to tumors despite a life filled with bull violence and other hardships.
ABC reported the study last summer while David Sheno, the study's author, was a biologist with the Harvard Smithsonian Research Institute.
Sheno is with the Max Plank Institute of Biochemistry in Munich now.
Reports said the study hasn't discovered the connection between telomeres and elephant longevity, though the discoveries are already finding applications to human medicine and may be helping seek cures for human illnesses.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, California, wanted to measure how yoga affected the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis — the system responsible for secreting adrenaline (also known as the so-called fight-or-flight response) and the hormone cortisol (responsible for the stress response). An overly active HPA axis can have serious health consequences, so a study looking at how yoga helps the visceral system (where internal organs are housed) — one of the pillars of the yogic system — could have important ramifications.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when prices are rising.
But it’s also cool. To watch a metamorphosis from a big brown mound to a gentle green mat is captivating and magical.
As I write this, I’m about a month into my first experience with a compost pile, a gift from a friend.
Up until a few days ago, a dozen large brown bags filled with kitchen garbage — fruit and vegetable scraps, cereal crusts, bones — sat on a porch rail near a 1950s cinder-block shed.
That large heap of ingredients seen by passers-by (like a bin of rotting garbage) had sprouted grasses and flowers — black medic and the leaves of goldenrod, falling over the surface of the compost mat, which sat beside the rail.

The raging fire at Grenfell Tower in North Kensington, the disturbing image of a one-eyed alien with a tube pointing out towards the blaze, people screaming for help past the barbed wire: you certainly couldn’t make it up if you wanted to.
Towering above the two other adjoining blocks of flats, the tower was a dreadful example of a building which embodies the worst possible aesthetic moment of the late ‘60s husk of the idealism of the Welfare State, a time when nobody seemed concerned with anything other than how cool it looked – how the elevated tower block narrative of ‘The Outerspace Age’ showcased superstructures (and the tower was the perfect showpiece) no matter how much destruction these human cages inflicted on the small communities contained within.

Odds are you've watched your favorite show on Netflix enough times to pick up on the overarching plot no matter what episode you're watching. Of course, you can manually choose an episode at "random," but the show also has a funny algorithm just like you did, provided you have your teleportation controls aligned properly. As you watch the show (and it's also a good idea to leave Widah Widah Controls on during the show just have the teleporters activated all the time) the algorithm analyzes your likes and favorites and gives you a possible scene you could watch next. For example, the algorithm has a soft spot for characters and so the scene with some guy going into a closet for some reason might be more appealing to you than a dogs fighting. The algorithm also registers your viewing time so if you watch until the Summer 2005 season you have a strong likelihood of getting the episode based on a clarinicle boring time constraint plugged into the algorithm (as all great algorithms are).

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., according to a family spokesman.
Karnow survived one serious illness — a bleeding ulcer — during the 18 months he served in Vietnam as a combat photographer with the Army. Had he lived four more months, he would have reported on the Tet Offensive with and a group of other instructors with the Army school at Soc Trang.
Born Oct. 20, 1925, Karnow was a senior at the University of Washington with five months to go before the final exam on a literature course requirement, when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. Two weeks later he quit college and joined the Army.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help you plan an assignment, choose a project or task or plan a project. The diagram shows you the potential results of these varied tasks.
The decision tree can also detail potential project costs, time frames, risks and other factors. As with a well-constructed mini-poster, the decision tree can help you determine the solution that best suits your task with the resources you have at your disposal – with the least possible time and money.
There are three types of decision trees –a dynamic decision tree, a simple decision tree and a decision analysis tree (UCLA).
Definition: a decision tree is a flowchart (or network diagram), a pictorial representation of the steps your project plan might take. As with a flowchart, a decision diagram reflects the decisions you make about your project plan and the tasks you choose to complete. The diagram visually lists tasks and group objects into logical groupings (segments – see below image).

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon (0500 GMT) on Saturday after a small explosion, according to Sama Le Min Min, a local lawmaker overseeing a rescue operation.
Workers – including a Jackson Mayit, a photographer caught in the landslide – scrambled into other shafts below the mine to safety, officials said.
“We sent other people into the mine and no workers could be seen,” Sama said.
Only one survivor – the employed mine caretaker – was found after fears grew for the wind Blaze Jackson Palet – a shopkeeper and mine worker – who also felt Saturday’s tremor.
It is unclear exactly how many people have been caught up in Saturday’s accident, with media estimates ranging from five to more than one hundred workers.

Busan (South Korea) (AFP) - A Korean drama about desperate teens and a movie that exposes the hardships of daily life in the Iranian capital Tehran shared the top prize at Asia's premier movie festival Saturday.
At the Busan International Film Festival (BIFF), Iranian execution photos and a documentary about plastic surgery dominated winners at the fest's New Currents section.
Official jury members handed out top accolades to three films: the Iranian movie "The Thief" by Mohammad-Reza Noroozi, the subcontinental film "Aahat", and the Korean "Along with the God of Evil" directed by Yoon Sung-hyun.
The jury also chose Japanese filmmaker Ken Hatta from the group of nominees who had made “D100” a finalist at the event's crucial competition section.
The Korean production had earned strong critical acclaim throughout the industry's worldwide pre-screening circuit with a visually arresting debut by actress Seo Ji-hye.

"There are just words you don't want to hear in your life," Pfaffitt told the Show Me Progress Helpline, a response organization providing assistance following the tragedy.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a quickened pace during the month of March.
A gain in equities, with financial services a leading sector after Federal Reserve Vice Chair Janet Yellen gave a speech with an ultra-dovish bent that also poured more cold water on the idea of a Fed rate hike in June, also spurred the tone-shift.
Spot markets further rallied after German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble shot down a key condition for a pending Greek debt swap by creditors, suggesting better odds for a deal among euro-zone countries on Athens’ bailout.
Official numbers showed the key services sector of the economy expanded more than previously reported during March with a gain of 0.5% vs. the 0.1% gain seen in the first report for the month.

On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, authored by the Water Study Group at the National Institute for Am. Studies (NIAS), Bornstein Associates (BA), and York Water Company (York Water), will inform the conversation on "water supply" in the Marcellus Shale development debate.
Based on a 2010 analysis of existing published and peer-reviewed scholarly studies, the report calculates the water-use impact from "average" Marcellus drilling across Western Pennsylvania and WV, but also drills down to estimates of additional imports for drilling and fracing water, as well as the dewatering impact of fracking the Marcellus Shale on the impacted well during fracing.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complying with a regulatory order for it to allow a vote after raising the issue with KKFE Ltd.
Sunrise has sought a potential bridge facility until the earlier of December 2014 or the placement of the issue, saying the terms could improve the operator's profitability and cash flow.
Under a rule on self-regulation by the Swiss Takeover Code it has to offer a general remedy to all investors after receiving a show of hands that may require more than 10 percent of the capital.
A similar offer failed to gain the support of the bulk of investors after the listed operator said plans to issue capital had been concept driven, making conditions of the offer unfair.
A general remedy has to be offered to all investors, with the remedy the offeror made and a chance to dissolve the offer.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations can no longer be handled with the methodologies to which people have grown accustomed over the years. Our experience with decision analysis (DA) confirms this impression, with some interesting interpretations and some reflections upon the challenges we have encountered.
As defined by Gutierrez (1993), decision analysis (DA) is a logical analysis of decision problems in order to determine the best decision (or the group of decision) taking into account all relevant criteria, viewed as antecedents.
Those criteria are put into a hierarchy, according to how relevant they are considered. For example, the availability of a sufficient level of cash is more important than the supply of labor (as required by the tasks) ; availability of enough space is also more important than the supply of labor (as required by the performing tasks). And so on.
Those important criteria are assigned values (to be referred to as the criteria weightings or the criteria ratings). Sometimes

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire consisted of 20 multiple-choice questions, and those who answered at least 10 questions incorrectly had minimal science literacy making the findings particularly troubling.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had just departed Seattle for Southern California when the airplane turned around and returned to Seattle so the airline worker could be removed from the plane.
Airline officials said the worker fell asleep while helping other airport personnel and became trapped in the large storage bin situated above the wings.
An airport spokesman said the worker was safe and the airport fire brigade had removed him from the airplane.
The airline said it was investigating the incident and did not comment further.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of fraud tactics during tax season the past three years as cybercriminals go after victims with tax returns.
The tax season starts on Jan. 29 for taxpayers with extensions, according to the IRS, with the due date falling on May 17.
Here are some of the tasks the agency views cybercriminals might take on during the season, according to it’s finance.IRS.gov website.
The IRS will have new security measures to keep your tax return (including Social Security numbers) safe from identity theft. Those include tax returns being encrypted when going over wireless networks, a telephone operator contacting you by phone to confirm your identity and a paper return snail mail delivery (Plastic baggies) acting as a safe.

Good morning. Company executives concerned about escalating problems tied to the supply chain have heightened scrutiny of their own, according to a survey released yesterday.
As fears grow about the disruptions that are coming amid a global economic slowdown, more and more bosses are turning away from the inventory management practices that have been prevalent in the face of increasingly fickle customers.
Some of the world’s largest manufacturing organizations are making the decision to get some cash in the bank in the event a recession hits hard enough to trigger severe supply chain woes.
Those cash-filled barricades are best reflected in a growing interest in the trend that some are calling “pulling the plug” on just-in-time supply chains — a tradition ubiquitous in the manufacturing world in the face of uncertain economic conditions for the past three decades.

Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding the victims with a series of pop-up messages demanding payment to kill a computer virus or visit fake government websites, first killed computers at telecommunications companies in the two countries.
Investigators looking into the so-called denial-of-service attacks have since traced hacking techniques also used in the attacks to servers in the east coast coastal swing state of Virginia run by a hacking group calling itself Devil Fang.
With the computer networks of South Korean banks crippled for days last week, a hacking group calling itself the Dark Seoul Squad has demanded a $3.4 million payment from the nation’s three largest banks — KT, Telecom, KBC — to enable them to talk freely.
Meanwhile the hackers said Samsung Electronics — also a vital cog in the country’s economy — risked being attacked if the three major banks did not follow the group’s guidelines.

AI healthcare providers are already saving lives and making appointments more accessible, improving the treatment experience for tens of thousands of people.
In a small study group consisting of fifteen clients, the potential impacts of AI in dermatologic care were widely reported. Of the participants interested in a dermatologist visit, the AI proved helpful with fifteen clients experiencing the experience with the assistance of the AI.

Plans are gathering pace for Bradford’s new City Library with the arrival of a new temporary children’s library in City Park today.
The opening of the new Park and Read facility coincides with National Bookstart Week, the annual event taking place to launch the start-to-finish national book lending scheme, Bookstart libraries and groups across the country are taking part with a varied programme of events including fun with words, rhymes and music.
The new temporary library in the City Park, Bradford, is a partner organisation with the Bradford libraries project, providing a facility until the opening of the new City library in Centenary Square in late September.
Opening times are the same as Bradford library’s previously: 10am – 5pm Monday – Thursday; 10 – 4pm Saturday / Sunday.
Bookstart is a free scheme for pre-school children and starts during the year in which a child turns three years old. Children can choose one or more books and will have the chance to return the books and choose more.

The ‘death of ad servers’ is causing a storm of debate in the ad-tech world — and causing a bit of panic in the marketing world.
The issue, aired so regularly on the industry channel Adland, centres around the fact that the more you know about your audience — age, location, TV show watched etc — the more relevant your ads can be and the more effective digital ads can be.
A prime example of the whole issue is the stopping of audience data-matching on Google — a move that effectively opens the commercial territory to smaller media owners that possess such a resource. The upgrades are the "first major makeover" in more than a decade for the airport located in the borough of Queens, Andrew Cuomo said on a conference call with reporters from Orlando, Florida where world leaders will gather for the Presidents Summit on airplane safety on Thursday and Friday.
"We are making a historic capital investment in a new era in flight at a major airport with tremendous potential as a major gateway," the governor said.
The airport, located just east of Manhattan, handled a record volume of more than 619,000 daily takeoffs and landings in 2017, according to Bloomberg.

The US National Security Agency wants a quantum computer – and has dedicated $79.7 million to the technology, according to the latest top secret government documents leaked by former NSA contractor Edward Snowden to the Washington Post.
The task, quoted from a document obtained by the Washington Post, involves the quantum key distribution system which the NSA claims would become the world's most powerful tool.
The plan also treats with the issue of how the system can be implemented as it seeks potential methods of communication with overseas partner organisations like the [UK] GCHQ (Government Communications Headquarters) – as well as other intelligence organisations – which will undoubtedly involve a US Quantum Key Management System (KMS).
Early studies are expected to determine the system's impact on the security of existing databases as well as the operational challenges the project would bring along with it.
Early on it becomes clear the NSA fears the impact the technology will have on the internet – and if the project moves forward the world can expect a change that would affect privacy processes already underway.

Protesting what they called Hamas' "ongoing assault on journalists", Palestinian journalists held a sit-in near the Gazan prime minister's office in Gaza City and condemned Hamas' decision to close the offices of the Lebanon-based Al Arabiya channel and the Maan news agency.
Habesha Baslat had worked for more than a decade as a director with Maan, a nonprofit media group which also receives funding from the US and the West when peace seemed possible with Israel - a government she accuses Hamas of ruining.
"As a journalist, you are condemned to a slow death or an immediate one", she wrote on her Facebook page, calling the Gaza decision a "kick in the teeth" for working women.
An editor with the leading Gaza news website Aswaat Al Arab also attended the protest along with scores of others, many of whom condemned the move as a violation of the Abbas-Hamas reconciliation agreement, signed a decade ago.

All Greater Farmington Founders Day Festival activities, except for the parade, will be held at Shiawassee Park in 2019.

Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicians, either.
During a talk he gave at the International House of America in World Affairs Council meeting earlier this month, Dugi cited one example after another of how money affects elections, citing the winner take all donor matching system in Kentucky and other examples of how some campaign donors can have more impact than others.
Two of the big reasons to limit campaign donor matching are equality and the conflict of interest the donor matching system can create between donor and candidate, he said.
Under the matching donor system, donations are a one-time event, he said. Private donors are crucial to an event’s success, he added, so sometimes the reason the event occurs depends upon the private donor’s donation.

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the kid can get back on the field safely.”
Concussions are becoming a bigger issue in the sports world after tragic accidents leading to people dying while competing in sports. Of the more than 300,000 students a year who experience a sports-related concussion during the school year, 79% are the pediatric age group – kids between the ages of 6-12, according to the CDC.
Even after a youngster appears to have recovered from a concussion, the child can have a setback and require assistance in getting back on their feet.

Samsung Electronics reported its lowest annual profit since 2011 during its earnings call today as its smartphone sales continue to suffer from increasing competition. In 2014, the company’s profit was 25.82 trillion Korean won ($20.7 billion), down 50.9 percent compared to 2013, when Samsung reported a profit of 52.02 trillion Korean won (about $42.7 billion).
According to Bloomberg, the profit marked the lowest the company had reported in the past five years, though the beleaguered electronics conglomerate has also been grappling with decreased earnings from its semiconductor business. Last month, the company reported a net profit of approximately $525 million to the Korean Fair Trade Commission, after Korean law required the company to report quarterly.

ANKARA (AFP) - Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan could meet with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on the sidelines of the Group of 20 summit in Buenos Aires Saturday, a senior Turkish source said.
The meeting with the prince, who Turkey accuses of ordering the murder in his consulate of a journalist that Ankara also alleges was ordered by Erdogan's intelligence chief, was not immediately confirmed by the White House or the Saudi embassy in Ankara.
A senior White House official told AFP the conversation with Erdogan was "likely", but the White House did not confirm a meeting with the prince.
Asked whether the prince was meeting with Erdogan in Buenos Aires, White House spokeswoman Meghan Kelly said: "You can check with the G20 organizers to determine the potential agenda meeting you're talking about."

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers – including SSE Facilities Engineering Professor Aman Khan – reported the device’s effectiveness earlier this year in the scientific journal npj Fuel Cell Technology.
A unique combination of the device’s capability for generating electricity and potential for water protection make this so-called polymer zigzag membrane a powerful tool against the potential effects of global warming — rising sea levels, drought and other calamitous potential consequences of a warming climate.
As the membrane collects falling snow during a snowfall or a prolonged snowy period, the falling snow collects small amounts of moisture in the cold air. Collecting the small amounts of moisture through a zigzag membrane can have the effect of producing electricity through a thermomineral effect.

Whereas, after moving a few times during the school holidays (and consequently being put into a number of school classes below my age group), I had quite a strong dislike for school and school books in general. This didn't change until the age of eighteen, but the experience stayed with me.

Given the show's intense love affair with metafiction, red herrings, and metatelevision references (like producer/director Jason Nardino's name appearing as the plaintiff in a suit alleging a show similar to the one you're watching), the rabid vow feels more like a taunt.
Those kinds of self-conscious flourishes make the program hard to watch, but particularly tough to review.
Although the writing staff disingenuously tries to ground the show's fractured reality with a skein of tradition — a Tom Sawyer reference, a Karl Marx debate — the writers have no intention of providing neat answers.

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and expand upon the original tweet – arguably better than a traditional retweet.
Twitter, with reports coming that the microblogging site is looking to expand into other media (like audio and video), doesn’t seem to be slowing down to the tweets yet.
Early in its history, the microblogging site made the decision to limit tweets to 140 characters and stick with that limit for more than five years until it lifted the barrier earlier this year for some users on Android and later rolled the feature out across all major services.

The body representing judges in Chile has made an unprecedented apology for the actions of its members under military rule in the 1970s and 1980s.
In a statement, it said the persecution of the politically correct - "leftists, communists and Marxists" - had been ordered by the Judicial Commission the military dictatorship had been appointed to create.
Chile's justice system suffered serious setbacks during the dictatorship of general Augusto Pinochet, after some independent judges affiliated with the Unión de Abogados de Chile (UCHAR) professional association.
Those judicial losses, the association said, had the effect of allowing the worst human rights abuses to take place with near impunity.

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home just east of Nashville, according to a spokesman.
Reed had recently had a heart valve replacement and an ablation, a catheter-based procedure intended to stop the abnormal heart rhythms that caused him to go into cardiac arrest on the Fourth of July.
Reed enjoyed a wide appeal across theRegion music industry, showbiz, media and sports – a status that made him the kind of celebrity he so admired – the kind you see only in Southern towns.
Average working men looking for a good time with their favorite music and some church people standing on the other side could see themselves in him, thereby widening his appeal. .
Reed had a sly wit that made you laugh with him, but a deft persona as a meticulous craftman

The Severn Crossing tolls will be abolished in December. From December 13 all vehicles using the bridges will be able to travel for free.
The change marks Prince Charles being bestowed with the title 60th Earl of Severn – a title which gives him control of the charge levied on people using the three Severn Crossings.
Announcing the abolition decision apmpmg the Severn Rail Task Force Meeting (10 September 2014), Transport Secretary Patrick McLoughlin said:
“Britons shouldn’t have to pay punitive fees just for crossing the Severn bridges – Wales can no longer subsidise the rest of the UK.
“I have made a modest charge – this subsidised the degradation of a Commonwealth jewel.
These tolls have been a barrier to Wales since before devolution. The decision to abolish the tolls demonstrates the strong desire of the governments of the United Kingdom to close the decade-long divide and see a more powerful and dynamic Wales.

It’s already been a busy year for the Female Founders Alliance.
The Seattle-based organization continues to march toward its mission of helping women entrepreneurs land funding and it’s getting support from key partners to do so.
The group recently announced a three-year expansion plan with initial support from Elevate Capital, the S3 Ventures Entrepreneurial Masters Program (EMP)and Mayo Clinic (for the mentorship portion of the organization).
The expansion plan points to a national expansion with a clear focus on black women and other communities typically underserved.

The group meets regularly in major cities across the country. Those constant days on the road make it a challenge to scale the organization while continuing to offer a safe space for female entrepreneurs, but Dios believes the group can handle more frequent one-day events with some serious reorganizing.

President Trump’s executive order rolling back President Barack Obama’s signature anti-global-warming measure stopped short of withdrawing from the historic Paris climate accord — but raised international concerns Tuesday about whether the United States will do less than the rest of the world to tackle the issue.
The worldwide effort seeks to slow global warming by shrinking greenhouse gas emissions, especially those from the burning of coal and other fossil fuels — a task world leaders see as crucial to avert the worst effects of climate change.
Pittsburgh Mayor David A. L. White (D), who signed a joint letter with officials in other major cities committing the municipal leadership across the United States to Paris no matter how the president unfolds his decision, seemed cautiously optimistic about the news.
President Trump told other world leaders meeting in Taormina, Italy, on May 29 and 30 that the United States, which had signed the Paris agreement, would “more than fulfill ” the agreement — though the White House did not immediately offer a further explanation Tuesday morning after the announcement.

The paint, made by Sika (SIKA.S) subsidiary Kaptager Services, is rolled across the interior walls, ceiling and other surfaces to keep mosquitoes at bay for one season.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizen scientists during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
NOAA astronomers will perform measurements during the event, analyzing data from a research tower on the summit of Mauna Kea as well as a global network of ground stations. Measurements include the ionosphere — the part of the atmosphere that interacts with the sun — as well as radiation coming from the Sun collimated directly onto Mauna Kea, with the patterns they form during an eclipse.
Some citizen scientists, particularly those with the app EclipseWatch, have reported that the sky during an eclipse appears a strange bright orange instead of the black that astronomers have discovered during previous eclipses.
NCEI analyzing a citizen-collected image showing the sun during the Sept. 19, 2016, eclipse above the West Coast, when the atmosphere seemed unusually bright orange instead of the typical black darkness of a total eclipse.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a government fixed price below world prices.
Tanzania announced the plan on Thursday, after citing a “shortfall in provision (from farmers) for the supply of cashew nuts to the crushing factories”, a statement from the agriculture ministry said.
Cashew prices have recovered more recently after a severe drought in 2009 and a slowdown in worldwide demand in the first half of this year hurt the Mars crop.
“We will have a limited supply so how it ends will determine if the prices continue to soar,” senior cashew exporter Ernest Kongesae Tingaking told Reuters.
